body:
Allows to get the scroll amount of a window.

Fixes #15247

comment_data.body: This seems like it Mixes bytecols and screencols.

Just as a thought, but instead of `[top, bot, left, right]`, we instead have `[row, col, height, width]`, where:

* top  = row
* bot = row + height
* left = col
* right = col + width

Just so getting the dimensions of a viewport is more convenient as I often find myself wanting these more often than co-ordinates, otherwise the user can just do `height = top - bot` and `width = left - right`.

Not a big deal either way.

comment_data.body: The thing is that the width will always be 5 here, as this is the width of the window

Is this true? From what I can make out, `w_leftcol` is a screen column.

What would be a test for this? The following testcases pass:

```lua
    it('follows columns with multibyte chars', function()
      local get_viewport, win = prepare_win ({ "あいうえお" })
      meths.win_set_option(win, 'wrap', false)
      feed '1zl'
      eq({0, 1, 1, 5}, get_viewport())
    end)

    it('follows columns with tabs', function()
      local get_viewport, win, buf = prepare_win ({ "\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta\ta"})
      meths.win_set_option(win, 'wrap', false)
      meths.buf_set_option(buf, 'tabstop', 3)
      feed '1zl'
      eq({0, 1, 1, 5}, get_viewport())
    end)
```

Width of the window but not the viewport. Plus we already have an API function for the window width. We currently have nothing that can be used to determine the margin which we have a direct use case for.
I am not sure I get what you want then, in your example, the last item is `1` which is wrong, it should be `5` here.

It is 1 because the margin is presumably 4 wide. The window width is 5, but the viewport width is 1.

Does this help?

![Screenshot 2021-08-17 at 13 38 06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7904185/129728152-502af1c1-18ae-4cba-a100-cd3e6c712594.png)

From this:
- `leftcol + viewport_width = rightcol`
- `window_width - viewport_width = margin_width`

comment_regular_data.body: I still need to get a little test working.

Can you explain in comments (and later docs) what _exactly_ "scroll amount" is?

What's the difference to `win_viewport` (the `ui` event) -- can that be leveraged here?

So:
- The first item (line) is the row index that is the topmost in the requested window (0-based)
- The second item (col) is the column index that is the leftmost in the requested window (0-based)

Why not give the full viewport (also bottom and right indices), like `win_viewport` does:
```
["win_viewport", grid, win, topline, botline, curline, curcol]
	Indicates the range of buffer text displayed in the window, as well
	as the cursor position in the buffer. All positions are zero-based.
	`botline` is set to one more than the line count of the buffer, if
	there are filler lines past the end.
```
Ideally, could reuse some the same code path?

Ah, but that doesn't include the horizontal viewport. That's a separate issue, then. Still, probably good idea to

1. future proof and also show the end indices,
2. use a similar name (`nvim_win_get_viewport`)
This will allow me to replace `vim.fn.line()` in gitsigns decoration provider.

~~Question: does the column index include or exclude the sign/number column? If so then this PR can supercede https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14392 and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13931~~

Ignore that, just realised the horizontal scroll is a different thing.
could be an option?
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14392 makes it an option to `nvim_win_get_width`, but maybe `nvim_win_get_viewport` is a better place.

The thing is that for me `viewport` is how much of the current buffer the user is seeing through this window.

Thus not that much related to the borders.
@clason any update on this ?
Looks good to me! (Can't comment on the actual code, though))
@bfredl I am not sure I know how to fix this `screencol` vs `bytescol` problem, do you have any solution ?
What's needed to progress this? I had a look myself, but I don't fully understand the screencol vs bytescol problem.
I might need that in Hop. Any idea on a merge ETA? :)
I think I need help from @bfredl (who can actually take the control of the PR) if he wants.
Note that this has become more complicated (and more useful) with the virtual lines feature in 0.6.0.

Related: UI clients like https://github.com/vscode-neovim/vscode-neovim want to _set_ the Nvim viewport / scroll position. Current workaround is to use `winrestview()`.
